qas.question: Many adaptations of the instruments were done to cater to what type of music?
What is the mandolin usually tuned to for Indian music?
There is no concept of what in Indian music?
What is another popular madonlin tuning?
These mandolin are used in a popular dance music called?
Many adaptations of the instruments were done to not cater to what type of music?
What is the mandolin usually tuned to for Asian music?
There is no concept of what in Asian music?
What is not a popular madonlin tuning?
These mandolin are used in unpopular dance music called?

context: Many adaptations of the instrument have been done to cater to the special needs of <a0_0><b5_0>Indian Carnatic<b5_0/><a0_0/> music. In Indian classical music and Indian light music, the mandolin, which bears little resemblance to the European mandolin, is usually tuned <a1_0><b6_0>E-B-E-B<b6_0/>.<a1_0/> As there is no concept of <a2_0><b7_0>absolute pitch<b7_0/><a2_0/> in Indian classical music, any convenient tuning maintaining these relative pitch intervals between the strings can be used. Another prevalent tuning with these intervals is <a3_0><b8_0>C-G-C-G<a3_0/>,<b8_0/> which corresponds to Sa-Pa-Sa-Pa in the Indian carnatic classical music style. This tuning corresponds to the way violins are tuned for carnatic classical music. This type of mandolin is also used in <a4_0><b9_0>Bhangra<b9_0/><a4_0/>, dance music popular in Punjabi culture.
